notes.content:
Framework for presenting to others. This assumes the presentation has a call to action.
1. Why does it matter to you?
2. Why should it matter to the person listening to you?
3. Why should we do it now?
A teacher's effectiveness is correlated to their ability to persuade their audience to care about the subject.
notes.source: ChooseFI podcase Episode: The Simple Startup

notes.content: Understanding your audience is important to effective teaching. Knowledge of an audience can directly increase a teacher's ability to motivate that audience to act/learn. This can be as important as a teacher's knowledge of the actual subject matter.
notes.source: ChooseFI podcase Episode: The Simple Startup

notes.content: Simplicity is an attractive and sought after attribute. It is also hard to define. In business, simplicity leads to adaptability, eases communication, spurs action, and is understandable.

We rely heavily on other's knowledge in society. This is referred to as Epistiemic dependence. We overestimate the individuals ability to amass information and underestimate society's role in processing it. Knowledge of the world depends as much on trust and relationships as textbooks and observations.
notes.source: Why you don’t really know what you know

notes.content: Scientific fields have become so narrowly specialized that collaboration is necessary for big projects.
notes.source: Why you don’t really know what you know

notes.content: We often overestimate our ability to explain things. This is referred to as the illusion of explanatory depth. Because of epistemic dependence, we often don't actually "know," (knowledge == facts you can support with data and logic) that much and it is put to the test when we must explain something in great detail.
notes.source: Why you don’t really know what you know

notes.content: Transactive memory is the phenomenon of knowing who knows certain information. This is observed in cases of subconsciously remembering more facts about a situation in which your partner is not an expert.
notes.source: Why you don’t really know what you know

notes.content: The servant leader is a leader whose focus is shifted from a profitable, thriving company to a leader that serves his followers and customers. This leadership style builds a foundation of trust in employees.

A company with a culture of trust has higher chances of sustained success. This is because trust is transformative to employees and customers. Employees are retained for longer and become more productive. Customers continually support companies they have high trust in.
Mistakes are important to long term success because we learn from mistakes more than learning from success.
In organizations, allowing members to make mistakes and being open about mistakes builds a foundation of trust and learning in the organization.
People want to work for and with companies that stand behind social causes. Therefore, companies will have more success by merging social and economic priorities.
A collection of talented people focused around a particular area or topic can be a very valuable asset.
A narrative/story has greater influence on people than facts.

The Ziegarnik effect is the tendency to remember interrupted or incomplete tasks more easily than tasks that have been completed or marked for later. Tasks linger in thought and are worked on in the background while pursuing other things. Tasks can be cleared from the mind by writing them down to do later or finishing them.
The difference between a tinkerer and entrepreneur is entrepreneurs solve problems for themselves and others while tinkerers solve problems for themselves.
Building passion for your idea in others is as important as harnessing your own passion.
Successful founders are deeply knowledgeable about their domain. This gives them good base of knowledge to innovate against.

Successful founders often did not know anything about their domain to start. This gives them the advantage of not having any biases or assumptions. They can freely challenge convention and question assumptions without the biases of being an expert.
Cofounders are essential to starting something, especially if that cofounder has a different skillset and perspective. They offer immediate feedback, a different perspective, and someone to trust.
Bootstrapping successfully for a long time is indicative of future success.
Bootstrapping is personal financing a project through any means possible. This can include personal funds, tapping connections, personal time, ingenuity, etc.
A straightforward way of understanding a user's mental model is to ask them to accomplish certain tasks on your website and see what they do.
Understanding why a company exists and being able to articulate that to others gives people a reason to believe in the company and ask further questions.

Iteration for entrepreneurs has two phases. Phase 1 is where the creator tinkers with an idea until they are satisfied. Phase 2 is when they release the idea to the public and tinker with it until it catches on. Successful pattern is to only spend as much time as necessary in phase one to get an idea that you believe in that can withstand the criticism that phase two invites.
Creators that cannot take criticism well get stuck in phase one of iteration and never create for others. They are fearful of criticism of their work and let that fear hide their ideas from feedback.
Responsive web pages serve content optimized for the client device which can range from a smart-watch to a desktop monitor.

There are many tools available to manage the complexity of responsive webpages. These are encapsulated by CSS. CSS is typically used to abstract away design and layout of a webpage from the functionality.
When designing responsive webpages, design for the smallest device and then add thresholds and layout choices for subsequently bigger screens.

D3.js is a low-level JavaScript library for manipulating the (DOM) Document Object Model with data to create visualizations. The primary abstraction it offers is to join data to DOM elements. It uses other web technologies like SVG to do the actual drawing in the browser.
Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is a markup language to describe 2 dimensional graphics. SVG is an open web standard.
Web standards are formal, non-proprietary standards for describing and defining aspects of the world wide web. These standards are created by standards groups like W3C and ECMA International.
Data visualization is a tool to help give meaning and insight to abstract data.
notes.source: Towards The Understanding Of Interaction In Information Visualization

notes.content: Interaction is a part of data visualization. It's effect on cognition is multi-faceted, varied and unknown in some cases. There are many different types and techniques of interaction in data visualization that all have different intended effects on cognition.
notes.source: Towards The Understanding Of Interaction In Information Visualization

notes.content: Participation and Collaboration is a category of data visualization interaction techniques that enable more than 1 user to contribute to the understanding and interpretation of a visualization. This leads to higher engagements from users and different insights derived from the data. This could be motivated from the idea that sensemaking and data interpretation tend to be social activities.
notes.source: Towards The Understanding Of Interaction In Information Visualization

notes.content: Sensemaking and data interpretation are social activities.
notes.source: Towards The Understanding Of Interaction In Information Visualization

notes.content: Api first is an approach to software building. It stresses to design, document, and debug the intended api before implementation. Often this means creating an OpenAPI spec and using tooling around it for sharing and documentation. This offers visibility and feedback in an enterprise or micro-service framework where other apis are dependant on the one being built.
In software, bringing in dependencies is taking on technical debt.

Willpower is a small but renewable resource. Decisions use this resource. Conserving willpower can be implemented by removing decisions from a system. A system that has fewer decisions will move forward faster

Technical debt is likened to financial debt. It is incurred to enable something sooner but must be paid off or will build interest and prevent future happenings. Likewise, technical debt impedes change to software if not paid off.

The beginner's mind (Shoshin) is a concept originating from Budhism. This is to put yourself into the mindset of a beginner. When contrasted to the mindset of an expert, the beginner''s mind has increase curiousity and playfullness with less bias
To be a good software engineer is to be a good thinker.

In the context of problem solving, the ego conflates self with thinking/problem solving. The ego becomes a distraction to thinking and problem-solving and limits the engagement between mind and actual problem solving.

Distancing ego-self from the problem/task can disarm the ego distraction. This is a reversal of the tying the self to the problem. This is shown by the following example statements. Distanced: What is the problem? Ego: Did I cause this problem?

The beginners mind is a way of removing the ego as a distraction. This tames the ego and shifts the focus from accumulated knowledge to knowledge seeking. Approaching problems from the beginners mindset rather than the expert's mindset puts more focus on the problem itself than the ego.

The golden ratio is 1:1.618. This means that the smaller item's size multiplied by 1.618 will equal the larger item's size. The golden ratio is aesthetically pleasing to humans and often found in artwork and nature.
notes.source: Golden Ratio. Bring Balance in UI Design.

notes.content: Visceral reactions are a psychological principle that describes the phenomenon of first impressions. People decide whether they like or dislike something faster than their consciousness can react.
notes.source: Golden Ratio. Bring Balance in UI Design.

notes.content: Design that uses the golden ratio has a higher chance of being positively viewed. The golden ratio is the unconscious expectation for design.
notes.source: Golden Ratio. Bring Balance in UI Design.

notes.content: People are more relaxed with what they are familiar with.

OpenAPI is a specification and standard for building REST API. The creation of OpenAPI specification came stemmed from SWAGGER which was created to address a lack of standard in place for creating APIs.
Standards are documents that give requirements, specification, guidelines, or characteristics with the intent of providing consistency, fostering cooperation, and increasing safety.
notes.source: Standards: What are they and why are they important

notes.content: After a threshold is reached, increasing levels of IQ is not a predictor of success. Success is more correlated with systems of organization than intellect.

Self control and self discipline are dependent on environment rather than individual. An individual can display greater levels of self-discipline and self-control in environments conducive to this purpose.

Elm programming language is a static typed functional front end programming language. It compiles down to JavaScript to work in the browser. Elm is known for having a developer friendly compiler and was built in a way to have minimal to none run-time errors.

The appropriate way to grow Elm code is to focus on specifying an appropriate data model with custom Elm types. As logic build up around certain types, it may make sense to make them modules and split code that way.

In Elm, building data structures can be done by mapping project requirements to custom types and further refining handcrafted/union types until structural problems are solved. Opaque types with accessors and mappers are a common pattern when building in this way.
The purpose of a module is to hide implementation details.

Good module design exposes as little detail as possible. By not exposing implementation details, using a public api cannot break the api and therefore there is less of a chance of introducing a bug from this contract. It can maintain invariants, a way to enforce rules that the data structure cannot. A refactor of the implementation details will not be a breaking change to the public api. This results in less refactoring for users of the api.

An invariant in programming is a property of the program state that is always true. For example, this could be a rule of a program enforcing that all lists in a view function have at least one member. An correct implementation of this view function will maintain this invariant.

Making impossible states impossible in Elm development is the notion to rely on the rigourous type system and compiler to enforce certain constraints imposed by the business logic that is being modeled by software.

Reducing decisions someone has to make in a given time can lead to more efficient actions and results. Uncertainty level is related to the quantity and quality of unmade decisions. Uncertainty about the results of future decisions can deter decision-makers from acting out of fear.
Generating buzz refers to getting a non-trivial number of people to talk about your company and/or product.
The success of a new business is predicated on the ability to generate buzz and engineer word of mouth.

An effective strategy to generate buzz is to get influential people to talk about your product. "Nobody cares about what a brand has to say about itself." Getting trusted sources to talk about your product in public is invaluable to generating buzz.
On average, people have 4 hours of free time in a day.
Word of mouth is to get product into peoples hands from recommendations of existing product holders.
The way to effectively generate word of mouth is too have a good product that is worth recommending to others.
During bleak periods in startups, changing perspective and taking a step back from the daily worries may allow founders to see patterns and what is missing to bring them out of a bleak period.
You need to be direct and specific in a crisis situation when directing others.
It is very difficult to change organizational routines and truces. Crisis situations make organizations malleable and more open to change.
Each action performed by a user requires a reaction from the system to keep users informed. When user's are uninformed due to a lack of feedback they are less likely to want to use the system

Feedback is used in interactive design to show users that they can and should interact with what's on screen. Feedback can tell a user where they are, the status of what happened, what will happen next, and what's currently happening.
notes.source: Feedback: 5 Principles of Interaction Design To Supercharge Your UI (5 of 5)

notes.content: First time user experiences have more success when users interact and learn by doing rather than be told or explained a program.
Users hate reading

Non-disruptive experiences for the user will be a more positive experience for the user using the app. Default configuration and inline cues are examples of non-disruptive patterns. Overlays and announcements are examples of disruptive patterns.
Most companies don't scale to unicorn levels. A majority of American companies are fewer than 20 people.
If you find other companies copying your idea/company, suing you, or doing both then you're probably doing something right.
When catastrophe strikes businesses with good foundational habits of trust and transparency, they are able to gracefully recover and keep trust with the public.
Habits that inspire broad change are called keystone habits. Keystone habits result in small wins. They also build a framework/foundation to build other habits from.
Small wins build momentum and show that larger, broader change is possible.

Cost benefit analysis of large scale social intervention is measured in average cost of dollars vs average dollars saved. For example, according to the Coppenhagen Consensus Center every $1 on iodizing salt saves $30 in healthcare costs and higher economic productivity.
notes.source: One man’s crusade to end a global scourge with better salt

notes.content: Well defined, meaningful and interesting tasks do not require willpower to execute.
Restrictions on a system facilitate creativity by limiting decisions. We increase our capacity for creativity by treating some things as a given or constant.
Restrictions free the mind from spending willpower because restrictions are decisions already made that don't have to be made again.

Graph theory is the study of graphs, where graphs are a mathematical structure to represent relationships between objects. This manifests as a collection of edges and vertices which can be used to model many parts of life like social networks and knowledge.

Creating data structures is an approach to building software applications. It is a thought exercise where you solve for structural problems before problems in isolation solving for the previous problem. This involves going through a cycle of building, discovering, and re-structuring until the structure can be realized with implementation.
Building with blocks is an OOP style where components are built in isolation and then stitched together. In this approach, isolated problems are higher priorities than structural problems.
Structural problems have a high cost to fix when the code is already implemented.
Software design is the activity following requirements specification and before programming.
The root of the urge to criticize another person is a signal or insight into the criticizer. This could tell them that they are in-secure with something related to the criticism.
notes.source: The life-changing magic of tidying up

notes.content: Human's inherent biases prevent a complete, objective study of human nature.
There are major social costs to Google's profiling behavior.
Most pivots do not go from bad to good ideas, but good to great ideas.
Founders driven by a mission often have higher resolve than those driven by money. This makes these more often successful because of the level of difficulty associated with startups.
A business culture is a collection of shared values emulated by the people who work for the business.
Businesses with strong cultures have greater chance of existing in the future, happier employees, and higher retention.

The monarch founder micro manages and merges their identity with the business. This approach leads founders to doing as much themselves as possible emulating the days of the early company. When a company starts to scale this behavior cannot scale with it.
Recycled materials have lost value over time. It is unclear why this is the case. One factor is that China has stopped taking the recycled product of other countries.
notes.source: Recycling in Chicagoland: We`re doing it wrong and soon it`ll cost more

notes.content: Recycling is a more efficient way of producing goods. When compared to virgin material mined from the earth, the energy it takes to produce 1 can can produce 20 cans from recycled goods. This information was not sourced and verified.
notes.source: What Happens to Your Recycling After It's Collected? | NowThis

notes.content: Fear is the apprehension of future events. Uncertainty that is either created or stems from this fear can deter action.

We procrastinate to cope with fear/anxiety over completing tasks. Procrastination can be a technique to avoid confronting this fear/anxiety and serve temporary relief. Procrastination can also be an act of defiance when we perceive we don't have control over a situation.

Negative self talk puts someone into a victim mindset which removes their perceived control over a situation and diverts energy from the task at hand to thoughts of what to do if they weren't a victim in this situation.
Negative self talk can lead someone to use the vehicle of procrastination to find relief from their lack of control of the situation

Guilt free play is vital to enable periods of focused, quality work. Guilt free play re-energizes and re-vitalizes the individual. Guilt free play tackles some of the root causes of why individuals reach for procrastination.

In the scope of doing quality work, one benefit from adding guilt free play regularly to a schedule is that it allows time for the Ziegarnik effect to take hold and inspiration strike during play time.
Learned helplessness is the phenomenon attributing an individual's unhappiness to that individual's perception of helplessness and their perception of a lack of control of their environment.
A well designed user interface behaves exactly as the user expects it to.
Tools that do not behave as expected can cause a user to feel helplessness and not in control of their environment.

A User Model is a user's idea of how a program works. The Program Model is how it actually works. The User Model is often unknown and can be researched through experiment. The user may also not know how a program is supposed to work at all.
It's often much easier to change the program model to adhere to the user model than to change the user model to adhere to the program model.
What helps people with big intellectual endeavors?
A users cognitive load is increased when they aren't told explicitly what to do.

Marking form fields with required/optional reduces a users cognitive load when filling out a form. Having this information elsewhere on the page increases the interaction cost of filling out the form. Coloring the required/asterisk red would conform with Jakob's Law since the rest of the internet does this.
Interaction Cost is the sum of mental and physical efforts a user must deploy in order to achieve their goal.

Users spend most of their time on other websites. Users prefer for all sites to work the same way as what they are used to based on their cumulative experience. Violating Jakob's law leads users to confusion. When users on the internet are confused, they often opt to leave sites.
notes.source: Jakob's Law of Internet User Experience

notes.content: Every option given to the user is a choice the user has to make. Making choices isn't inherently bad, but making choices about something the user doesn't care about is certainly bad.

Activity Based Planning is designing a UI around activities a user intends to do with the application. This is in contrast designing around the capabilities of an app. Activity Based Planning is meant to have user centric design and make these activities as easy for the user to do as possible.
The natural limit of a group bound by gossip, intimate acquaintance, is 150. This is reflected today from human organizations.
notes.source: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind

notes.content: An imagined reality can exert force in the real world as long as there is collective belief in it.
notes.source: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind

notes.content: Evolutionary psychology comes from the belief that present day social and psychological characteristics were shaped from sapiens thousands of years as hunters and gatherers. Thus behaviors can be explained by studying humans at that period of time.
notes.source: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind

notes.content: Myths and stories allow sapiens to cooperate with high degrees of flexibility at large numbers/any scale.
notes.source: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind

notes.content: Every intellectual endeavor starts with writing. Writing helps us remember. It also helps us organize the thoughts in our head.
Big intellectual endeavors like writing a paper are impossibly hard when starting from scratch.

We can optimize the success of big intellectual endeavors by writing down what we learn with a good organization system for the purposes of big intellectual endeavors. Becoming better at writing what we learn and using better organization will give greater success.
The discipline to use better organization uses self control/discipline.
Intellectual endeavors rely on insight. We generate insight through research and application of that research to our existing theories.
Insight cannot be planned for.

Working inside of a structure allows people to gather research efficiently. Good structures free people from procrastination issues and motivation issues. Good structure allows people to access the flow state.
Flow state is where time is hard to perceive and work becomes effortless.

The slipbox note taking system is to keep ideas individually with links between ideas. The ideas are written clearly with full sentences in your own words. Then entry points into the slipbox in the form of questions are the start of conversations.
Smart notes combines the slipbox systems with routines that allow you to focus on the task at hand.
A habit is defined by a decision made once. This decision is repeated without as much thought in future situations until it is like muscle memory.
In the face of large amounts of data, we have a tendency to seek information that confirms our pre-existing biases.

Out of sample errors are errors of forecasting where a situation was predicted based on historical data but the situations that this data was collected are different than the situation currently being predicted on.
People are prone to out of sample errors due to the human tendency of ignoring contrary data and seeking information to confirm our own assumptions.
Writing provides an external scaffolding for our mind to understand ideas. We write to think.
Most of what we learn, we do not plan to learn.
We think about and work on many concurrent problems at once.

A bottom up process that takes advantage of our natural tendencies can make intellectual endeavors approachable and more successful. The bottom up approach to intellectual endeavor has our existing knowledge dictate what projects to follow. Contrast this with a top down approach of deciding what to do and hoping that research will give enough info to follow a pre-determined path.
Linking notes in the slipbox note taking system is done to further develop existing ideas.

There are two categories of thinkers, hedgehog and fox. Hedgehogs tend to ascribe to big ideas and governing principles to understand the world. Foxes tend to gather smaller ideas and be okay with nuance and dissonance.
Foxes are more accurate forecasters than hedgehogs in aggregate.
We can be more objective by understanding the influence our assumptions have on our forecasts/perspective and then question those assumptions.
Objectivity is correlated with success.

Thinking probabilistically is to recognize that our subjective perceptions of the world are approximations of the truth and present a range of outcomes to reflect our perceptions rather present a singular outcome.
Probabilistic approaches with ranges of outcomes more accurately reflect real life situations.
Asynchronous collaboration is enabled by good communication and good writing.
notes.source: No Meetings, No Deadlines, No Full-Time Employees

notes.content: Because the bottom up approach relies on us gathering information, it is subject to our biases leaving our eventual intellectual endeavor at risk of being biased.

Spending time gathering information from places where people don't often spend time and thinking about information from many different perspectives can yield insights that give a competitive advantage.
Better forecasts can come down to who has more, higher quality data and can analyze it rigorously to limit personal bias.
Commoditizing user attention propagates existing biases among people in name of profit.
notes.source: Big Tech’s attention economy can be reformed. Here’s how.

notes.content: Good systems remove complexity and allow us to focus on the important part of the task at hand.
Chaos theory applies to non-linear and dynamic systems. Where non-linear means exponential rather than additive and dynamic means the behavior at one point in time affects future behavior.
Chaos theory systems are hard to model and predict. Very small discrepancies in data quality can have sizeable effects in prediction.
Working as if nothing else counts than writing. This is a guiding principle of taking smart notes. Working with this principle makes for a more engaged reader and listener.
Working as if nothing else counts than writing is a keystone habit. A behavior with a cascading effect to different parts of life.
The age of a source may be contextually relevant. Information from the past has a chance to be outdated.
Over fitting is modeling the noise of a sample size instead of just the signal. Over fitting often occurs when a data set is sparse and the theoretical understanding of the data is not good.
Over fitting is dangerous because it can claim higher accuracy and crowd out better models to the true signal. This can set progress back in the science or discipline by years in some cases.
Building applications in technology is really expensive
The path to consistent success with technology is to do the minimum possible to validate the market opportunity/assumption

The slipbox system changes the framework we think in for note organization. Traditional note taking systems put the focus on where to store notes for future reference. Slipbox does not expect the user to remember every single note. It asks "which context do you want to stumble upon this note again?" The slip-box gives you ideas you already forgot. This emphasizes thinking and connecting over categorizing and memorization. This makes this system more useful over time as it's used more without increasing complexity unlike other organization systems.

Without understanding the theoretical basis of a model, forecasting can be inaccurate because the available data could be skewed or misrepresented. It's hard to know if data is sparse or well represented without some theoretical understanding.

Bayes theorem derives the probability of an event based on prior probabilities and the likelihood of an event given x event. Repeatedly applying Bayes theorem and testing hypothesis can enable hypothesis to converge to truth. Bayes represents how humans interpret the world by explicitly stating our prior predictions and applying that knowledge to the event at hand.
What makes an effective leader?
Leaders craft the environment they want to live in. They build strong cultures of shared values.
How do we collaborate with others effectively?
We can collaborate effectively by recognizing the individual strengths of the collaborators.

Work that is self propelling is sustainable work, where we do it because that is what fulfills us. A growth mindset coupled with feedback loops to check if we are growing/learning enables sustainable work.
A growth mindset is to have pleasure in changing for the better.
Smart Notes framework creates feedback loops when working inside of it. Translating readings to literature notes, permanent notes, and making connections all test understanding.
Different tasks require different kinds of attention from narrow focus to broader creative thought. Big intellectual endeavors are comprised of many different tasks.
Successful individuals in different fields are often adept at deploying different levels of focus or attention when working
Conway's law states that the software systems of a company will reflect it's communication systems.
Communication is necessary to collaborate.
Metacognition, thinking about thinking, is deployed to solve complex problems.
A heuristic are mental shortcuts that ease the cognitive load.
A commitment to making bets and testing our hypothesis is the best way to accelerate the learning process and the only way to progress.
To be competitive in something you have to be only relatively competitive, better than your competition/opponents.
Big intellectual endeavors often give something to the world that did not exist before or do something better or different than what has been done before.
Result oriented thinking can mis-attribute skill where luck played a substantial role. This leads to blind spots and inaccuracies in future endeavors.
Coming up with a probabilistic answer to a question can often be better than a yes or no. This more clearly communicates the underlying uncertainty of a situation.
Feedback is needed when collaborating.
Praise in public, criticize in private
Challenging the status quo will lead to people reacting defensively.
Our beliefs should converge toward one another as we are presented with more evidence over time when applying a Bayesian mindset according to Bayesian convergence.

A leaders job in medium to big companies is to define and enforce company culture comprised of real values and ratify good decisions. Straying from these roles is a sub-optimal way to work. This means avoiding setting strategy or tiebreaking.
Real values are deliberate choices that in a vacuum are not better or worse. Example: We will ship buggy code to meet a deadline.
Defining what success means for a project or body of work can give clarity to collaborators by allowing them to concretely identify what is needed to reach success.
Empathy and consensus enable collaboration and collective action.

Individuals collaborating on a project with a clearly defined goal can build empathy and consensus by applying a Bayesian framework towards their goal and thinking probabilistically. Collaborators laying out plainly what they think and updating their prior probabilities with bets on what will happen will build empathy. Bayesian convergence given enough time will build consensus.
The availability heuristic suggests we over-predict things we're familiar with and under predict things we're not as familiar with.
We have holes in our knowledge that we don't know about that we tend to make bad assumptions about and this leads us to bias our thoughts. Some refer to these as unknown unknowns.

Maintaining a hierarchy of principles gives a framework to make decisions. This framework allows you to violate principles to maintain higher priority ones. Principles can 
 be in conflict with each other through cognitive dissonance.
Exposing our ignorance is one method to overcome "you don't know what you don't know."
When an organizations values are in disharmony or you're changing the values of an organization, it will be painful.

Looking at events from a mathematical perspective makes it possible to convert unknown unknowns into unknown knowns. This method can subvert our unconscious bias makes the seemingly implausible more plausible.
The business model of the big internet companies like Facebook and Google is to sell the ability to tweak the behavior of it's users.
What problems are we facing as a result of tech companies?
How do we learn things that we don't know (unknown unknowns) and understand the bias of what we do know?
Social platforms are not just tools that enrich your life. They have been designed as rabbit holes that need things from you and steal your attention.
User attention is spent on platform with behavior that maximizes generating revenue for the platform in place of behavior that maximizes life enrichment of the user.

When ingesting information from a source, it is important to understanding the veracity of what is being said, to have the ability to judge fact from opinion, and to understand how the author is framing what is being said. This allows the receiver to see what is being communicated more clearly. They will be able to frame the information in their own way rather than simply use the framing the information was delivered in.
notes.source: News & Noise - The Cozy Robot Show

notes.content: We expose ourselves to differing and diverse viewpoints to reduce our chances of bias. Views can be treated like a spectrum and there are many spectrums in life. With this definition, we can define differing and diverse viewpoints as views from different ends of the spectrum.
When learning new techniques, it can useful to envision how those techniques could have improved prior situations.
Do research on your subject matter to understanding what's already been done and give inspiration for what else is possible.
notes.source: Episode 411: That Photo Makes Me Hungry with Andrew Scriviani

We experience food in real life, we do not observe food. Photography can reflect the experience rather than the observation. If you think about experiencing food as continuous motion, then food photography is a snapshot in time capturing the kinetic energy surrounding food. This spans the process of creating food to eating it.

sources.title: The signal and the noise
sources.author: Nate Silver
sources.content:
When the amount of data available to us increases at a rate eclipsing our ability to understand this data, our productivity goes down. In the face of large amounts of data, we have a tendency to seek information that confirms our pre-existing biases. Our ability to make predictions is hindered by this and predictions drive many of our decisions in a day. 

Out of sample errors are errors of forecasting where a situation was predicted based on historical data but the situations that this data was collected are different than the situation currently being predicted on.

People are prone to out of sample errors due to the human tendency of ignoring contrary data and seeking information to confirm our own assumptions.

There are two categories of thinkers, hedgehog and fox. Hedgehogs tend to ascribe to big ideas and governing principles to understand the world. Foxes tend to gather smaller ideas and be okay with nuance and dissonance.

Foxes are more accurate forecasters than hedgehogs in aggregate.

Three guiding principles to becoming better forecaster are to think probabilistically, update forecasts when better information becomes available, and understand when you're deviating from consensus.

Thinking probabilistically is to recognize the existing uncertainty and present a range of outcomes to reflect reality rather present a singular outcome.

We can be more objective by understanding the influence our assumptions have in our forecasts and then question those assumptions.

Better forecasts can come down to who has more, higher quality data and can analyze it rigorously to limit personal bias. Insight to gain a competitive advantage often comes from really low level or high level thinking on a problem. Basically spending time in perspectives that not many people spend time in can give information that no one else has.

Chaos theory applies to non-linear and dynamic systems. Where non-linear means exponential rather than additive and dynamic means the behavior at one point in time affects future behavior.

Systems with these qualities are hard to model and predict. Very small discrepancies in data quality can have sizeable effects in prediction. 

We can evaluate a forecast based on it's accuracy, truthfulness(was it the best forecast that the forecaster could have made), and economic impact. Forecasters sometimes have incentive to skew forecast results leading to worse accuracy.

Over fitting is modeling the noise of a sample size instead of just the signal. Over fitting often occurs when a data set is sparse and the theoretical understanding of the data is not good.

Over fitting is dangerous because it can claim higher accuracy and crowd out better models to the true signal. This can set progress back in the science or discipline by years in some cases.

Models are approximations of the real world. Models that perform better are sophisticatedly simple, especially in cases where the real world behavior is exceedingly complex. Predictions themselves have influence on the real world, they can be self fulfilling or self defeating. Over simplifying or over complicated models each have their own problems. Since models are approximations, they'll all be wrong, but perhaps the path forward is to be less wrong each time and understand what made them more wrong in the first place.

Bayes theorem derives the probability of an event bases on prior probabilities and the likelihood of an event given x event. By repeatedly applying Bayes theorem and testing out own hypothesis, we will be able to converge to the truth. Bayes represents more explicitly of how humans interpret the world by explicitly stating our prior predictions. Frequentists on the other hand attribute errors in prediction to the data collected rather than a lack in the predictor.

Computer are useful to do computation very quickly but otherwise have limitations in their usefulness. Computers can also produce the equivalent of "unconventional thinking" in a sense that unless programmed to do so it does not have the bias of a human with expertise in a prediction. On the other hand, computers can't turn garbage into gold. Theoretical understanding to enable relevant data must be used for computers to produce meaningful results and forecasts.

To be competitive in a field you have to be only relatively competitive, better than your competition/opponents. Generally, this means that in highly competitive fields you'll have to put in disproportionate amounts of effort to outcompete others rather than lower competitive fields. The pareto learning curve is related here as we often put far less effort to learn the first 80% than the incremental learnings take far more effort. 

Thinking beyond result orientation is to recognize the role luck plays in many aspects of life and focus on self improvement. This is recognizing that results could be a combination of luck and skill or luck in spite of skill, to rigorously evaluate predictions and understand if we're succeeding because of increasing skill or happen stance. To accept that noise and signal will always exist.

Stocks allow people to make bets constantly to help refine their Bayesian probabilities. These act as aggregate forecasts in a way. Some view the market as unbeatable, others view the market as very very hard to beat. Like earthquakes, the market is somewhat understood in broad strokes but not understood in the short term at the same time. It is complex and dynamic. One reason the market may not be perfectly priced at all times is because not all players have the incentive to maximize profit, there are constraints on some market functions, and people behave irrationally due to herd behavior and have overconfidence in their own predictions.

Healthy skepticism weigh new evidence against the overall strength of the theory rather than cherry picking facts that support or deny your opinion. This is exactly what Bayesian analysis is.

There may be dissonance when problems and decision making are on different scales. I.E. global warming is a global problem(co2 in one part of the world affects another) but governments/decision makers are regionals

Consensus is general agreement as opposed to voting with majority.

The availability heuristic suggests we over-predict things we're familiar with and underpredict things we're not as familiar with. If something is unknown to us, it's unfamiliar to begin with. This leads us to not being able to predict an unknown situation.

Looking at events from mathematical perspective makes it possible to convert unknown unknowns into unknown knowns. It makes the seemingly implausible more plausible when we look at relationships between events this way.

Designers often think it looks crude to mark a form with metadata being required is repetitive and ugly. However, there are benefits to the user from explicitly marking forms. Additionally, there is a higher interaction cost to filling out a form if a user has to search or think if a form field is required.

To reduce a users cognitive load, mark form fields with either the word required/asterisk or the word optional. Making the asterisks/required word red may be better as this is what users are expecting.

sources.title: How I Built This
sources.author: Guy Raz
sources.content:
There are many different motivations leading to entrepreneurship and ideas can come from many places. A tinkerer solves problems for themselves. An entrepreneur solves problems for themselves and others. Building passion for your ideas in others can be just as important as harnessing your own passion.

People are more relaxed with what is familiar. Scary things often lead to inaction. Uncharted territory like starting a business and leaving a stable paycheck is unfamiliar and scary. However, regretting inaction can be dangerous.

There are two common patterns when quitting the "real" job to go on an entrepreneurial adventure that are "safe" exists.
1. Quit when the time demanded of the venture requires it.
2. Have a fallback plan should the venture fail.

Most successful founders are deeply knowledgeable about their domain. This gives them the basis of knowledge to innovate against and allows them to trust their instincts. Often founders start with no knowledge in their domain. This can be an advantage. Not knowing anything allows more freedom to challenge convention question assumptions more readily.

Cofounders are essential. Better for a cofounder to be your opposite with a different skillsets. They offer immediate feedback, a different perspective, and someone to trust. 

Bootstrapping is personal financing a project through any means possible. Bootstrapping successfully for long period of time is indicative of future success. Bootstrapping is also uncommonly successful and very difficult.

All companies have a story. Understanding why a company exists and being able to tell that story to others is what allows others to believe in the company, to have loyal customers, to have others believe in the mission.
Getting OTM (Other peoples money) to fund what you cannot yourself is a draining, brutal process. Often, people start fundraising from their inner circle(friends, family) before going to venture capitalists. There is a level of privilege involved with access to resources but everyone has inner circles to start with.

Iteration for entrepreneurs has two phases. Phase 1 is where the creator tinkers with an idea until they are satisfied. Phase 2 is when they release the idea to the public and tinker with it until it catches on. There is no defined time limit for each phase. Creators that are scared of criticism do not move to phase 2. Spending enough time in phase 1 is necessary to withstand the criticism of phase 2 and have a product to believe in and stand behind.

Most startups are not completely new ideas. There is usually existing competition. This competition can create barriers to entry which can stop traditional paths to success in the domain. Rather than take the traditional path, 'going through the side door' is the concept of circumventing the barriers to entry through non-conventional approach.

Where the startup is located matters a great deal to the founder. Depending on need, startups have moved to areas to break in to industry and top talent, to areas to be isolated, and stayed where they were.

Hundreds of thousands of businesses start each year. Only 80 percent make it past their first year. The success of a new business is predicated on the ability to generate buzz and engineer word of mouth. This matters even more than the quality of the idea. Generating buzz refers to getting a non-trivial number of people to talk about your company and/or product. Companies with large budgets pour money into advertising. An effective strategy to generate buzz is to get influential people to talk about your product. "Nobody cares about what a brand has to say about itself." Getting trusted sources to talk about your product in public is invaluable to generating buzz.

Word of mouth is to get product into peoples hands from recommendations of existing product holders. The way to effectively generate word of mouth is too have a good product that is worth recommending to others. Little is more valuable to a business sales than the recommendation of a trusted friend.

The trough of sorrow is the period before product market fit where the startup is not profitable. During this period founders usually think about quitting and experience their most difficult times with the company. The solution usually comes in the form of changing perspective. A situation that may seem hopeless in the weeds of it could actually turn around if the startup is only a couple of pieces away from profitability.

Most companies don't scale to unicorn levels. A majority of American companies are fewer than 20 people. Almost all resource intensive companies require venture capital money to fund. It can be very  challenging to raise this money. This is in part because while venture capitalists may understand money, they don't understand the business as well as the entrepreneur. To get their money founders have to convince them of the idea.

Protecting what you've built is very hard. It is a skill to know when to sue to protect ep and when not to sue.

Catastrophe can strike any business. When catastrophe strikes businesses with good foundational habits of trust and transparency, they are able to gracefully recover and keep trust with the public. They do so by living into their values, this trust with the public is not eroded. Quick and decisive action with transparency is paramount to retain trust

Change happens can occur slowly and all at once in many aspects of life, including business. When this change occurs, it can result in businesses pivoting from their model to another. Pivoting requires recognition in some form. It could be the recognition that while the initial idea worked okay, a concept inside of it was the real driver of success. This is what was when Glitch transformed into slack. It takes courage for a founder to recognize that the initial idea is not what is propelling the business forward and to move forward with something else.

Founders driven by a mission often have the resolve to go through trials and tribulations that motivations of money often won't given them. A mission can help guide a company after they go from surviving to figuring out what to do next

A business culture is a collection of shared values emulated by the people who work for the business. Businesses with strong cultures have greater chance of existing in the future, happier employees, and higher retention. The monarch founder micro manages and merges their identity with the business. This approach leads founders to doing as much themselves as possible emulating the days of the early company. When a company starts to scale this behavior cannot scale with it. Delegation to people of shared values is behavior that does scale. Building cultures stems from the leadership on down. Writing down shared values and distributing them can be a way of communicating what the culture is without being a part of it.

"Think small, act small and grow bigger." Solving smaller, non capital intensive problems adjacent to booming sectors can be a recipe for success.

Managing conflict between founding partners can be difficult. A pattern to make it easier would be to establish responsibilities between the two and clear lines of communication.

Personal identify struggles can bring themselves to your startup company. Knowing yourself can help shape companies into a unified front with a stronger culture and larger mission. Not knowing where you're going can lead to everyone going multiple directions and disarray.

Founders selling their business can be an emotionally charged experience.

Building something that will last will have a higher success rate if kindness is involved. Being kind empowers employees to be their best selves at work and provides great retention. Not only can a founder be kind, to create a work culture of kindness they have to be kind from the very beginning.

Everyone has some luck, what you do with luck is up to you.

sources.title: How to Take Smart Notes
sources.author: Sönke Ahrens
sources.content:
Every intellectual endeavor starts with writing. Writing helps us remember. It also helps us organize the thoughts in our head. 

We can optimize the success of big intellectual endeavors by writing down what we learn with a good organization system for the purposes of big intellectual endeavors. Becoming better at writing what we learn and using better organization will give greater success. 

Insight cannot be planned for. Intellectual endeavors rely on insight. We generate insight through research and application of that research to our existing theories.

Working inside of a structure allows people to gather research. Good structures free people from procrastination issues and motivation issues. Good structure allows people to access the flow state where work becomes effortless. 

People need a place to store information as their own minds aren't reliable enough. A good storage system is simple and reliable. This system should not grow in complexity as it becomes bigger.

The slipbox note taking system is to keep ideas individually with links between ideas. The ideas are written clearly with full sentences in your own words. Then entry points into the slipbox in the form of questions are the start of conversations. 

Smart notes combines the slipbox systems with routines that allow you to focus on the task at hand. 

Writing a paper is complex and can be overwhelming. Writing a paper can be broken down into simple, concrete steps that individually are not overwhelming. 

A bottom up process that takes advantage of our natural tendencies can make intellectual endeavors approachable and more successful. 

We collect ideas through the day as we follow our interest. Store them somewhere, link them to previous ideas with the purpose of further developing our existing ideas. Eventually we have complex strings of ideas that ask to be turned into papers. We take these ideas, refine the arguments and see where gaps are missing, and eventually a paper is formed from following our interest everyday. 

Top down would be to choose a paper topic and research and hope we find enough information.

Our natural tendencies:

Writing provides an external scaffolding for our mind to understand ideas. We write to think. 

Most of what we learn, we do not plan to learn. 

We think about and work on many concurrent problems at once.

Good systems remove complexity and allow us to focus on the important part of the task at hand.

Work as if nothing else counts than writing.

Approaching reading or talking with this mindset will make someone more engaged as a reader and listener. 

Acting as if nothing counts other than writing is a keystone habit. A behavior with a cascading effect on different aspects of life.

Simplicity is the ideal to strive to as it makes systems useable. The note taking system was built so that it became more useful rather than less useful over time. It's overall goal is publishable insight.

This system changes the framework we think in for organization. Rather than "which topic do I store this note in" we ask "which context do I want to stumble upon this note again?" The former system breaks down in usefulness. It is designed to find things you're deliberately looking for. This becomes harder with growth. The slip-box gives you ideas you already forgot changing the focus from remembering to thinking.

To achieve critical masses of notes, it's important to distinguish three categories of notes, fleeting notes, permanent notes, and project notes. Failure to do this results in systems that grow less useful as they get larger.

Permanent notes are permanently understandable and contain the necessary information to be understood without additional reference.

Writing is presented to students as a linear process that starts with choosing a topic to narrow your focus and subsequent research. This is a bad approach as insight cannot be planned for and there is no guarantee that after a period of research there will be insight to write about. A better approach is to let previous months and years of research inform what to write about and to use smart notes to already have most of the work done in the first place. This allows the student to do what they want in the moment rather than being gridlocked into a topic and they still come out ahead on productivity.

Work that is self propelling is sustainable work, where we do it because that is what fulfills us. We can get there by creating habits to make work effortless. A growth mindset is to have pleasure out of changing for the better, the reward of a habit loop. To know that we got better, the habit loop must become a positive feedback loop and our learning system must enable feedback loops. The feedback we use to assess if we improved and must happen often to regularly assess if we grew. With smart notes, this happens regularly with translating readings to literature notes, permanent notes, and making connections.

We are bad at multi tasking even though many think they are good at it. Multi tasking, switching attention between tasks, dramatically lowers performance. Multitasking lowers our ability to focus. Big intellectual projects require different forms of attention like narrow focus and more creative attention to tackle the variety of tasks necessary to accomplish big projects. Successful individuals in different fields are often adept at deploying different levels of focus or attention when working.

sources.title: Towards The Understanding Of Interaction In Information Visualization
sources.author: Ana Figueiras
sources.content: [Source](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283855695_Towards_the_Understanding_of_Interaction_in_Information_Visualization) Data visualization is as a tool to help give meaning and insight to abstract data. This paper proposes that interaction is a part of data visualization. The effect on cognition/understanding when interaction is introduced to data visualization is varied not causuly known. This paper proposes that one reason for this is that the world does not have a wholistic view of what interaction is and encompases. There are a few reasons for this. Data visualization techniques continue to evolve and grow. As of 2015, there is no accepted standard for data visualization categories. To have a holistic view of interaction, this paper attempts to solve the lack of categorizing in visualization. For refererence, the visualizations Ana collected are documented [here](https://rethinkingvis.com/#all). ### Interaction Categories 1. Filter: This enables a user to reduce complexity to help cognitive load or to focus in on details. This is usually done by specifying a range of condition. Long delays between user filter request and machine response have shown to be detrimental to user experience and negatively affects user insight derived from the visualization. 2. Select: This enables a user to mark or track items of interest. This technique is often used in conjunction with others. For example, when an item is selected often that action is coupled with changing the visual representation of the data or offering details on demand, more detailed information about the selection. 3. Abstract/Elaborate: This enables a user to change the level of detail/abstraction for interpretation. Zooming allows users to remove detail/data points from view and show more detail about selected data points. Zooming out does the reverse and adds previously hidden contextual information back to the viewport. This helps aid cognition in recognizing meaningful patterns within data. Details on Demand provides users additional information upon a selection, often a click or hover state. Drill down options in tree diagrams use this technique. 4. Overview and Explore: This enables a user to see the entire represntation of a dataset. This can allow for insight that was only possible with the entire context of a datasets shape. Due to dataset size and other technological constraints, representing all data in a visualization may not be possible. Panning can be introduced when this constraint exists. This can be likened to a camera moving across a larger visualization. Often, there is a visualization to show how much of the entire visualization is being covered by the current viewport. 5. Connect/Relate: This enables a user to more clearly see view relationships between data. THis can manifest as highlighting similar data across multiple different graphs or physically linking data with highlights. 6. History: This enables a user to see the history of their interactions and potentially undo their interactions chronologically. This is highly associated to the exploration of data within a visualization. This aids a user to refine insight and make mistakes which can save user time. This also frees users from fear of not getting back to a certain view and can give users the freedom of exploring data further. 7. Extraction: This makes it easier for users to save or share derived insight from data visualization. This can manifest as translating query parameters across visualization or exporting content to different mediums. 8. Refigure and Encode: This gives user more direct control over the visualization to tranform it to gain insight. Possible examples of these techniques are allowing a user to change spatial reprentation of the data by ordering ascending when it was descending data points. This can also manifest as changing data groupings and colors. 9. Participation and Collaboration: This enables more than 1 user to contribute to understanding and interpretation of a visualization. This is motivated from human psychology. Sensemaking and data interpretation are social activities and offer benefits that were harder or not possible on an individual level from anything like insight derived to additional engagement. Techniques that allow for social insight include tags, links,bookmarks, doubly linked discussions, graphical annotations, comments, etc. Often, comments are the only technique used within this category as these can be difficult to implement. 10. Gamification: Indulsion of game mechanics or game design patterns can improve the user experience and engagement with the content. Examples include narrative context, reputation mechanics, levels, time constraints and goals.

sources.title: The life-changing magic of tidying up
sources.author: Marie Kondo
sources.content:
Employing the Kon-Marie method not only tidies the house but can give perspective and life-style change. Kondo throughout the book relates her life story as it applies to her tidying journey and how she came to the method that she teaches today. First, kondo motivates the need for a tidying education in the first part of the book. She asserts taht tidying is not formally taught in any capacity, school or from parents. She has also observed that tidying is not usually learned through experience. Therefore, it takes dedicated study to learn to tidy. Kondo motivates the need for a good tidying method further by saying existing tidying methods and idealogy are not often successful and result in rebound to a messy state. Tidying involves answering two questions about items in question, "Should i get rid of it?" followed by "Where should I put it?". Additionally, to prevent rebound she asserts that a lifestyle change is neccessary to not build up clutter again. 

The Kon-Marie method optimizes being surrounded by happiness in the household. The method is to systematically work your way through every item in your house broken down in order by category (clothes, books, papers, komono, mementos). You must hold each item close to you and ask if that item brings joy to you. It is important to keep in mind here that we are asking what to keep, not what to get rid of which is starkly different to common tidying methods. If the item does not bring joy, thank it for it's service to you and move on from it. If the item does bring joy, you keep it and decide where to put items after discarding is done. There is a little more nuance but that is basically it. 

She has a few suggestions for storage of items and how to start the process. She says before starting the process, take time and envision the space you want to live in to give clarity to decision making. She also suggests when deciding places for storage, optimize the decisions around ease of putting away. If something is easy to put away, it will be less likely to add to clutter in the future. Every item having it's own place in the house is also important to avoid clutter. Further, vertical storage is preferred to horizontal and when folding clothes try to aim to fold into a rectangle. Sentimental items can be difficult to discard even though they no longer bring you joy. To deal with this case and others, Kondo suggests to ask what the purpose of the item was and has it already served it's purpose. Kondo also suggests to store papers by category, papers to deal with and documents needed to keep. Keep each in a separate place, perhaps a bin or clear folder.

The mindset change is a big part of the Kon-Marie process. She recognizes that it is tough to change your mind or habits. To address this Kondo asks that you do her process all at once instead of little at a time. This is so you see results immediately and allow the best opportunity to change our mind. Kondo asserts that we can build empathy for messier individuals after being confronted by many decisions through the process. Through this process you will naturally have more appreciation for what you own and also build further appreciation for what you own. Kondo relates her experience that after her clients complete her method they have new-found clarity in their life. They are more decisive in their wants and desires out of life and act on this. This could be because they have been training their decision making process and fine-tuning what brings them joy among their possessions.

sources.title: Start Something That Matters
sources.author: Blake Mycoskie
sources.content:
The Tom's story is about a company that helps fight poverty by giving a pair of shoes to someone for every shoe sold. Blake believes in the power of story. He argues that a good story is an effective way to influence people. That could be influencing them to care and buy your product or work with you. He asks for the reader to find the story they care about, refine it and share it with everyone.` 

Fear is the apprehension of future events. Fear can influence us into not taking actions we ewant to do. Fear is ineveitable. Our response to fear is not. There are many techniques and ways to overcome fear. You can find situations that mirror the one you're fearful about and see the results to lessen uncertainty about your own situation. Transfer the fear from inside the mind to another medium like spoken or written to get a new perspective on the fear and impact of fear. Waiting for the right time to act may be a poor strategy as this stems from fear of acting.

Be resourceful without needing resources. A lack of resources can make shape decision making positively as this situation reinforces ingenuity and frugality. A lack of resource at onset can even be correlated to future success of a project/company. Traditional things like office space are not neccessary to succeed today.

Simplicity makes business easier. Simplicity makes decision making easier, working with others easier, and communicating about your business easier. Simplicity offers clarity of thought not just in business but in the personal life as well. This clarity of thought can spur the individual to action and allows them to focus on their values.

Higher levels of trust in and about a company is correlated to higher levels of success. Trust is built over time. A leader can foster a culture of trust by embodying the "servant leader," leading through empathy rather than authoritarian practices. Transparency can be a key element to foster trust. Giving individuals autonomy and room to make and learn from mistakes can be critical to building trust. Actions that break trust can be devastating to a company and fixing this mistake can be very costly. 

Charitable work as a core part of the business is advantageous as people have a predisposition to want to work for and be part of charitable work. There is also great personal satisfaction for many people in giving back. The best time to make charitable work a core part of the business is at the very beginning so it is part of the DNA of the company. Give early, give often and give thoughtfully. Money is fine to give but think about the core competency of your business and try to be charitable in that way. For example, a shoe company can donate shoes to poverty stricken countries rather than give money to a foundation in that country. The advantages here are a greater sense of engagement and sustainable effort.

Start something that matters. If you haven't started already, start today.

sources.title: Make Data Structures
sources.author: Richard Feldman
sources.content:
Make Data Structures is a live talk by Richard Feldman found [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x1FU3e0sT1I)

Richard compares and contrasts different ways of building software applications. Building with blocks is an OOP style where components are built in isolation and then stitched together. In this approach, isolated problems are higher priorities than structural problems. This can be a problem as structural problems have a high cost to fix when the code is already implemented. Richard advocates in Elm to create data structures before writing any code. This is a thought exercise where you solve for structural problems before problems in isolation solving for the previous problem. This involves going through a cycle of building, discovering, and re-structuring until the structure can be realized with implementation. In Elm, building data structures can be done by mapping project requirements to custom types and further refining handcrafted/union types until structural problems are solved. He asks to default to "opaque", cannot be modified, types with accessors and mappers instead of allowing use of the implementation. 

He brings in one more semi-unrelated theme of learning by doing. He thinks one of the best ways to learn is to just learn by getting deep in code without knowing what is proper and figuring out the proper way to do things later.

sources.author: Elmtown Podcast
sources.content:
Elmtown Podcast found [here](https://elmtown.simplecast.fm/its-just-darth-vader)

Aziz Erkal is the guest of this episode. He created [Kite, an interactive visualiztion tool for graph theory](https://github.com/erkal/kite). Graph theory is the study of graphs where graphs are a mathematical structure to represent relationships between objects. This manifests as a collection of edges and vertices which can be used to model many parts of life like social networks. Erkal is a mathemetician who wanted to an interactive graphing tool to help him in his work. He started to build this tool in javascript but was slowed down for a couple of reasons. Coming from mathematics, an imperative language like Javascript where the state of the variable could change confused him. He moved to Elm to be more in his comfort zone working with a declarative language. Because he didn't know what exactly he wanted to build as he was building, the freedom that came with re-factoring in Elm was beneficial. D3.js is the biggest known graphical library for the front end and he used that to interoperate with Elm at first before eventually re-factoring to use only Elm as dependencies for his tool He found the elm-geometry and elm-ui great libraries to work with in Elm and was encouraged by talks from the Elm founder and major contributor, Evan and Richard. He benefit a lot from the elm-community so he decided to make one of the latest features for Elm itself to give back to the community.

sources.title: D3JS Data Visualization Fundamentals
sources.author: Lars Verspohl
sources.content:
Pluralsight course by Lars Verspohl

Lars covers D3.js in depth at a conceptual level and shows examples to illustrate the concepts covered. To have an in-depth understanding of what D3.js offers, he has to introduce the audience to other concepts fundamental to creating data visualization.

D3 is a low-level Javascript Library for manipulating the document object model(DOM) with data. D3 is a collection of modules. The core abstraction it offers is binding data to dom elements. By binding data to dom elements, the dom elements can size, transform, shape, color themselves to the specification creating informative visualization. The data join produces data categorized into differnt data change states; enter, update and exit state. D3 uses web technologies (HTML, SVG, CANVAS) to actually do the drawing in the DOM. D3 offers many helper libraries on top of the core data join abstraction. This ranges from functions to help scale data to the screen/pixel locations to stratification of data for hierarchical structure to user interaction infrastructure to capture user and browser events.

D3 is a low-level library. It offers a lot of control of dom manipulation to the user. Because of this it can have a higher learning curve to use than other higher-level libraries that require the user to know less. The following concepts are all useful to know when working with D3.

- General Update Pattern: This pattern exists to take advantage of the D3 data join. As a consequence, code becomes structured to abstract dyanamic parts of the code from static.
  - Create or get an existing d3 dom element, join new data to this element to create the data state categories, then deal with each category of data states programatically

- Visual Design: This is a field of study to enhance usability/readability and reduce cognitive burden for understanding visuals. Understanding visual design concepts and patterns is key to making more effective visualization.
  - Transitions are used to reduce cognitive load by making it easier to follow data. They help maintain object constancy.
  - Interactions have many different consequences as there are many different types of interactions available with data visualization. For example, Highlighting can reduce distraction while tooltips can serve additional information about a data point.
  
- SVG: Lars focuses on using SVG as the drawing tool. SVG defines a canvas of an absolute pixel length. This canvas accepts children elements like line, circle, and text. SVG offers the ability to group children together and apply transformations to the group.

- Re-usable module pattern: The intent is to create modules to share configurable data visualizations created from D3. It suggests to have sensible defaults for configuration and use chainable function calls after object instantiation. One way this can be achieved is via closure.

- Data Structures: It is impossible to create certain visualization unless data is structured in a way that allows for it. D3 has some helper libraries to move and re-structure data. It is important to understand what kind of data, format of data, and structure of data to know what visualizations are then possible to create to answer questions about the data.

Lars also offers a couple systematic approaches to common problems. 

- For data visualization in general, he recognized this cycle. 
  1. Define the goal
  2. Source, shape and clean the data
  3. Draw the data
  4. Collect insight
  5. Refine goal
  6. Go back to step 1 if not satisfied

- For drawing data, Lars recognized this pattern.
  1. Sketch desired visualization
  2. Fetch and transform data
  3. Chart dimensions
  4. Calculate scales
  5. Join data and draw
  6. Add Axis 
  7. Refine drawing

sources.title: Artificial general intelligence: Are we close, and does it even make sense to try?
sources.author: Will Douglas Heaven
sources.content:
https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/10/15/1010461/artificial-general-intelligence-robots-ai-agi-deepmind-google-openai/?utm_source=engagement_email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=site_visitor.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=editor-favorites&utm_content=12.20.subs&mc_cid=7baa7ebed7&mc_eid=56dbda6dfa

AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) is more of a dream/vision than a concrete definition. Suposedly the last invention man will have to make, AGI is the concept of machines having general human-like intelligence with the capacity to learn new tasks exponentially and have a conciousness or some combination of these ideas. This concept divides AI researchers, some are focused on closer/easier to solve problems while others have this dream as the motivating factor. For AI researchers, managing expectations of research results is important as unrealistic expectations in the past have dried up research funding for a quite a while. AI today has advanced to a one-algorithm model where AI can do one thing exceedingly well through deep-learning/Neural Networks. To advance further to generalize these AI, there are some methods like transfer-learning, implementation of "common sense" and others that could be a next step. Future visions of AGI seem to have a few camps. One that this can be a brute force problem and we will eventually achieve it by massive computation. Another is that we have to map the model of the human mind more precisely and replicate that in machines. And of course, many think that a combination of both will get us closer to AGI. Advances in AI today don't necessarily mean that we have gotten any closer to AGI and timelines for AGI are nebulous given it's nature.

sources.title: Lie detectors have always been suspect. AI has made the problem worse
sources.author: Jake Bittle
sources.content:
https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/03/13/905323/ai-lie-detectors-polygraph-silent-talker-iborderctrl-converus-neuroid/?utm_source=engagement_email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=site_visitor.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=editor-favorites&utm_content=12.20.subs&mc_cid=7baa7ebed7&mc_eid=56dbda6dfa

There is huge interest in the ability to detect deception. The limitations of polygraph tests are well known. There are now many projects and companies developed to produce deception detectors using AI/deep learning to develop complicated models to solve these problems. There are many criticisms of these technologies. In the article, critics often pointed to small training and test data sets that may show these technologies to be unreliable when put in real world settings outside of controlled labs with homogenous test subjects. Further, there is a lack of pyschological research that states that deception can be correlated to human behaviors that also can be generalized to all humans. There were also ethical and moral concerns regarding building products like these that could erode human trust, especially in cases where the model was incorrect. Because the science behind these technologies is not trusted with what the technologies are being used for, the article conveyed that we are far away from a legitimate lie detector.

I found it interesting that some companies were founded off of research insights. Like, X research was done to and now we have Y insight about the human behavior/science/other/etc. Is this a common pattern for companies?
